channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:description: A health care worker in protective gear treated a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last month.

item.title: Live Updates on Trump Rally: President Heads to Tulsa Amid Racial Unrest and Virus Fears
item.description: His remarks will come a day after the Juneteenth holiday and during a period of nationwide protests and discussions over racism.

item.title: Protesters Demanded Police Reform. Minnesota Lawmakers Left Without Passing a Bill.
item.description: The Democratic-led House and Republican-led Senate, which had approved competing plans, failed to compromise before a weeklong special session ended.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at the Minneapolis State Capitol this month after George Floyd was killed in police custody.

item.title: Coronavirus Updates: Latest News and Analysis
item.description: The Australian state of Victoria is bringing back preventive measures after a sudden spike in cases. As people gathered in Tulsa, Okla., for a campaign rally by President Trump, health officials worry that the gathering could fuel the virus’s spread.
item.media:description: Delivering food to residents in a locked-down area of Beijing this week.

item.title: 6 Books to Help You Grasp How We Got to This Moment
item.description: The current protests are unprecedented in their number, scope and impact, but their newness is built on a long past, one that scholars have grappled with for decades.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
Locking Up Our Own: Crime and Punishment in Black America (Book)
Old in Art School: A Memoir of Starting Over (Book)
The New Jim Crow: Mass Incarceration in the Age of Colorblindness (Book)

item.title: How the Shooting of Breonna Taylor Changed the Kentucky Senate Race
item.description: With a war chest of $40 million, Amy McGrath was considered a safe bet in the Democratic primary. But the recent movement for racial justice has elevated the candidacy of her African-American rival, Charles Booker.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: Erik Branch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Charles Booker, a Kentucky state representative, is running as an unabashed progressive, supporting policies like “Medicare for all” and the Green New Deal.

item.title: The Walls of the Church Couldn’t Keep the Trump Era Out
item.description: The young pastor wasn’t sure his congregation would like what he had to say and had no idea where it would lead all of them. He found himself at a crossroads of God, Alabama and Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:description: Chris Thomas delivering a sermon at First Baptist Church of Williams in Jacksonville, Ala.

item.title: What to Know About the Tulsa Greenwood Massacre
item.description: As many as 300 people were killed in 1921 when a white mob attacked the Greenwood district of Tulsa, a thriving black community, and burned it to the ground.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Alvin C. Krupnick Co./Library of Congress, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke billowed over Tulsa, Okla., after a white mob massacred hundreds of black people and laid siege to a prosperous black business district in 1921.

item.title: Joni Ernst and Donald Trump Could Both Be in Trouble in Iowa
item.description: Iowa seemed out of reach for Democrats not too long ago. Now, the presidential race appears to be tightening, and Senator Ernst, a Republican, is facing a strong challenge from a political newcomer.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: The crowd outside a rally for President Trump in Des Moines in January. He carried Iowa by nine percentage points in 2016.

item.title: How the Pandemic Has Affected Passports, Global Entry, T.S.A. PreCheck and More
item.description: Travel is gradually returning, but not without disruptions. Here’s what to expect when applying for official travel documents and membership in security programs.
item.dc:creator: Tacey Rychter
item.media:description: A Transportation Security Administration employee checks the identification of a traveler at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport in Arlington, Va., in May.

item.title: 2 Sentenced to House Arrest in Long-Running Scheme to Steal Rare Books
item.description: The board chair of the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh said the thefts “will forever raise doubts about the security of all future charitable donations, particularly to the Carnegie Library.”
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: The Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh, where the authorities say more than $8 million in rare books and other items were stolen over 20 years.

item.title: What Time is Trump's 2020 Campaign Tulsa Rally
item.description: Will the thousands of Trump supporters wear masks? What time is the rally? How will President Trump talk about race? What protests will he face? Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni, Astead W. Herndon and Katie Glueck
item.media:description: President Trump will hold his first rally since March 2 on Saturday in Tulsa, Okla.

item.title: Pence Won’t Say the Words ‘Black Lives Matter’ in an Interview
item.description: On Juneteenth, a holiday that honors the end of slavery in America, the vice president said that “all lives matter’’ but twice declined to say that black lives matter.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vice President Mike Pence said that Americans had cherished the idea that everyone is created equal “from the founding of this nation.”

item.title: ‘Into the Wild’ Bus, Seen as a Danger, Is Airlifted From the Alaskan Wild
item.description: The Alaska Army National Guard transported the bus to a “secure site” after two hikers have died and at least 15 have had to be rescued while trying to reach the bus in the remote Alaskan wilderness.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson

item.title: Tribes in a Battle for Their Share of Virus Stimulus Money
item.description: Legal fights over how a pot of $8 billion should be allocated have complicated distribution to some of the nation’s poorest and most vulnerable communities.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Mark Walker
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:description: A woman gets a test for Covid-19 at a drive through testing center in Monument Valley, Ariz., in the Navajo Nation.

item.title: Judge Weighs Administration Request to Order Bolton to Try to Pull Back Book
item.description: A lawyer for President Trump’s former national security adviser called the request “theater,” portraying it as legally and practically impossible.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: The Room Where It Happened: A White House Memoir (Book)
item.media:description: John R. Bolton, President Trump’s former national security adviser, said in his book that the House impeachment inquiry into Mr. Trump was not broad enough.

item.title: Mueller Report Details Highlight Trump’s Interest in Emails Damaging to Clinton
item.description: The Justice Department had kept the newly revealed information secret while it was investigating Roger Stone and released it in response to a lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Roger J. Stone Jr. has expressed hopes that the president will pardon him.

item.title: The 1865 Handwritten Order Marking Juneteenth Has Been Found
item.description: The order to inform Texans that “all slaves are free” was found in a Union Army records book in the National Archives in Washington on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin

item.title: U.S. Watched George Floyd Protests in 15 Cities Using Aerial Surveillance
item.description: From Minneapolis to Buffalo, Homeland Security officials dispatched drones, helicopters and airplanes to monitor Black Lives Matter protests.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Brooklyn this month. Department of Homeland Security aircraft filmed demonstrations in New York and at least 14 other cities.

item.title: Lynika Strozier, Who Researched Early Plant DNA, Dies at 35
item.description: She overcame a severe learning disability to become a scientist with “golden hands” and most recently a college instructor. She died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Probe of Old Drug Cases Raises Questions About 2004 George Floyd Arrest
item.description: Mr. Floyd was arrested in Houston over a $10 drug transaction. Now thousands of cases involving the officer who arrested him and his squad are under review.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez
item.media:credit: Karen Warren/Houston Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gerald Goines, a former Houston police officer, turned himself in at Houston’s Civil Courthouse last year.

item.title: Elizabeth Alexander on the Spectacle of ‘Black Bodies in Pain’
item.description: The writer reflects on her seminal Rodney King essay, the George Floyd killing and how the videos of police brutality exacerbate black grief.
item.dc:creator: Salamishah Tillet
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Elizabeth Alexander in Manhattan. Her recent essay for The New Yorker grapples with what it means for a new generation of African-Americans to be able to access and process black death on new media technologies.

item.title: Iran Is Accused of Hiding Suspected Nuclear Activity
item.description: The United States and the big European powers came together to declare they had serious concerns about Tehran’s failure to allow inspectors into two locations.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, which is facing new accusations that it hid nuclear activity.

item.title: Navy Inquiry Faults Two Top Officers Aboard Roosevelt for Handling of Virus
item.description: The Navy will not restore Capt. Brett E. Crozier to command of the nuclear-powered carrier, and the promotion of his boss will be put on hold.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Capt. Brett E. Crozier was fired in part because of fears that the president wanted him gone for calling attention to infections aboard his warship.

item.title: As Annexation Looms, Israeli Experts Warn of Security Risks
item.description: Unilaterally taking territory the Palestinians have counted on for a state could cement Benjamin Netanyahu’s legacy. It could also destabilize the region.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: A Palestinian protest against Israeli annexation in the Jordan Valley. Israel may annex up to 30 percent of the occupied West Bank as soon as July 1.

item.title: Biden Proves an Elusive Target, Adding to Trump’s Frustration
item.description: Few politicians delight in seizing on the news of the day, or even the hour, to ridicule their rivals as President Trump, but Joseph Biden has been mostly off camera and avoiding gaffes.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. met with small business owners in Yeadon, Pa., on Wednesday.

item.title: In California, Hanging Deaths of Two Black Men Summon a Dark History and F.B.I. Scrutiny
item.description: When two men were found hanging from trees in Southern California, the authorities quickly ruled them suicides. After an outcry from activists, investigations were opened.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango and Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A large American flag fluttered over a memorial for Robert Fuller, who was found hanging from this tree in front of Palmdale’s City Hall on June 10.

item.title: Louisville Police Move to Fire Officer Involved in Death of Breonna Taylor
item.description: Brett Hankison blindly fired 10 rounds into a covered door and window, according to a termination letter.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy and Sarah Mervosh
item.media:description: People carried a photo of Breonna Taylor as they demonstrated in New York on her birthday on June 5.

item.title: Juneteenth 2020 in Photos
item.description: Nationwide protests against racism and police brutality give new urgency to a holiday long cherished by African-Americans.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: A child picked out a free book on Black Lives Matter Boulevard in Washington, D.C. on Friday.

item.title: Policing Bill Will Test Whether a Rusty Senate Can Still Legislate
item.description: Without an opportunity for debate and changes, the effort is likely to collapse as so many others have in the risk-averse chamber.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, and other Republicans ahead of a news conference to discuss police reform legislation in the Capitol this week.

item.title: Black Tulsans, With a Defiant Juneteenth Celebration, Send a Message to Trump
item.description: The president arrives in a city that is in the midst of addressing long-ignored racist history. People there believe the country as a whole could learn a lot from them.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Chris Creese for The New York Times
item.media:description: People looked over a Black Lives Matter street mural on Greenwood Avenue in Tulsa on Friday. The neighborhood will host a Juneteenth celebration later in the day.

item.title: Judge Expected to Approve PG&E Plan to Resolve Bankruptcy
item.description: A federal judge could decide on Friday that the California utility can put itself back together in time to take part in a crucial wildfire liability fund.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Peter Eavis
item.media:description: Pacific Gas & Electric will have big challenges ahead even with the shield of the $20 billion liability fund.

item.title: Top State Department Aide Resigns Over Trump’s Response to Racial Unrest
item.description: Mary Elizabeth Taylor, one of the administration’s highest-ranking African-American officials, said the president’s stance on racial justice was at odds with her core values and convictions.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Jahi Chikwendiu/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Mary Elizabeth Taylor was the only African-American senior official at the State Department.

item.title: Vote-by-Mail Ballot Requests Overwhelm New York City Elections Agency
item.description: For the biggest city in the country, a dramatic and fast expansion of the mail-in voting system has come with challenges.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: Lynn Cartwright-Punnett’s absentee ballot for New York’s primaries arrived with no return envelope.

item.title: On a Pennsylvania Farm, ‘Nature Is Not Just Carrying On’
item.description: Quarantine in the country means fresh air and space, but a writer’s sense of good fortune is darkened by the state of nature. “What I’m observing is unsettling,” she says.
item.dc:creator: Daryln Brewer Hoffstot

item.title: Trump’s Juneteenth Tweet: A Warning to Protesters at His Tulsa Rally
item.description: The president issued a thinly veiled threat to anyone planning to demonstrate at his campaign rally on Saturday, but drew no distinction between peaceful protesters and “looters or lowlifes.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Trump will hold a campaign rally in Tulsa, Okla., on Saturday, his first since the pandemic shut down much of the country.

item.title: Trump Says Administration Will Try Again to End DACA
item.description: Responding to Thursday’s Supreme Court decision, the president said he will follow the rules set out by the justices to challenge the Obama-era program protecting young immigrants from deportation.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: The effort to end DACA has been a centerpiece of President Trump’s strategy on immigration.
